This PR actually only resolves the issue for two ProtocolClassHierarchy merge. It would allow a CLR deserialized Configuration to be added to another deserialized Configuration. The merge between CLR and JVM class hierarchy is still not supported. This is because ProtocolClassHierarchy doesn't have all the data required by ClassHierarchy.
Test case added and review comments are addressed.

[Reef-pull-request-windows #261](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-windows/261/) UNSTABLE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

[Reef-pull-request-windows #262](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-windows/262/) UNSTABLE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

I've rerun the tests two more times and the results are following:
- Build 260 failed at `FailDriverTest`

```
Tests run: 12, Failures: 1, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 95.058 sec <<< FAILURE! - in org.apache.reef.tests.fail.FailDriverTest
testFailDriverAlarm(org.apache.reef.tests.fail.FailDriverTest)  Time elapsed: 6.756 sec  <<< FAILURE!
java.lang.AssertionError: Unexpected error: java.lang.RuntimeException: org.apache.reef.exception.EvaluatorException: Evaluator [Node-1-1429968123541] is assumed to be in state [RUNNING]. But the resource manager reports it to be in state [FAILED]. This means that the Evaluator failed but wasn't able to send an error message back to the driver. Task [FailTask_FailContext_Node-1-1429968123541] was running when the Evaluator crashed.
    at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:88)
    at org.apache.reef.tests.TestUtils.assertLauncherFailure(TestUtils.java:43)
    at org.apache.reef.tests.fail.FailDriverTest.failOn(FailDriverTest.java:64)
    at org.apache.reef.tests.fail.FailDriverTest.testFailDriverAlarm(FailDriverTest.java:117)
```
- Build 261 was done without the changes from this PR by mistake.
- Build 262 failed at `FailTaskTest` and gave a different error at another place.

```
Tests run: 7, Failures: 1, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0, Time elapsed: 89.986 sec <<< FAILURE! - in org.apache.reef.tests.fail.FailTaskTest
testFailTaskClose(org.apache.reef.tests.fail.FailTaskTest)  Time elapsed: 60.213 sec  <<< FAILURE!
java.lang.AssertionError: expected:<FAILED> but was:<FORCE_CLOSED>
    at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:88)
    at org.junit.Assert.failNotEquals(Assert.java:743)
    at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:118)
    at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:144)
    at org.apache.reef.tests.TestUtils.assertLauncherFailure(TestUtils.java:39)
    at org.apache.reef.tests.fail.FailTaskTest.failOn(FailTaskTest.java:52)
    at org.apache.reef.tests.fail.FailTaskTest.testFailTaskClose(FailTaskTest.java:91)
```

Also, I found some cases that tests failed similarly from the history, which makes me think the failure does not have to do with this PR. @markusweimer Do you have any clue?

This pull request looks good

Unfortunately, our build servers right now only test the java side of REEF. And yes, we seem to have an issue with those tests, which sometimes fail on the Windows build server. That is probably worth looking into. My hunch is that it is a timeout that is set to strict in our tests for the HW spec of the build server.

That being said, the change here reliably breaks the REEF.NET tests. Are you setup to run those? If not, I can debug them on my end and see what happened.

I'd like to do it by myself, but unfortunately I don't have the .NET
environment. Could I ask you a huge favor to debug the tests on your side?

Please let me know if there is anything I can help you.

Thank you so much.

2015년 4월 28일 (화) 오전 12:24, Markus Weimer notifications@github.com님이 작성:

> Unfortunately, our build servers right now only test the java side of
> REEF. And yes, we seem to have an issue with those tests, which sometimes
> fail on the Windows build server. That is probably worth looking into. My
> hunch is that it is a timeout that is set to strict in our tests for the HW
> spec of the build server.
> 
> That being said, the change here reliably breaks the REEF.NET tests. Are
> you setup to run those? If not, I can debug them on my end and see what
> happened.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-reef/pull/163#issuecomment-96704361.

I ran the tests again on my work machine and here they pass. It seems to have been a fluke with my setup at home. Just to be sure, @jwang98052, @beysims can you please run tests on this? If they pass for you, I'll do the merge.

[Reef-pull-request-ubuntu #423](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-ubuntu/423/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

In general, the `RemoteManager` constructors don't feel very nice, because the user has to be aware of how the `hostAddress`-`localAddressProvider` and `listeningPort`-`tcpPortProvider` pairs interact to use them. Is this something we want to clean up?
@dafrista Cleaning up the constructors would be great. Should we register a separate issue?

@bgchun These constructors are reflected in the newly introduced Factory interface as well. It might make sense to first clean these up before introducing the new interface (and possibly having to change the interfaces as well). @markusweimer since you've made the PR, I think it's fine if you decide :)

I agree that the remoting part in Wake could benefit from an overhaul. This PR is a tiny step in that direction, to get rid of calls to `new` and imports of `DefaultRemoteManager`. Hence, I think it could go in, but we should definitely follow up with a more complete cleanup. This part of Wake and Tang have been co-developed, which explains the plentiful use of `new` in it. It would be great to loose some of that in the process.

@bgchun: You designed this early on, do you want to take a stab at creating an umbrella JIRA?

Yes, NuGet.Target is system provided file. May be a safer way is to override some targets or property groups in build.prop or a separated target file for building and pushing packages because we do need to add our version number and customized stuff there. And we need to make sure overriding is working. May be a separate jira.

```
        at org.apache.reef.wake.remote.impl.DefaultRemoteManagerFactory.getInstance(DefaultRemoteManagerFactory.java:125)

        at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:57)
        at sun.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45)

```

The actual constructor _is_ obviously there in the code (it compiles).

`getInstance` is called from within the `MesosRemoteManager` injected constructor, and the `DefaultRemoteManagerImplementation` is also an `@Inject` constructor. I wonder if this is something Tang doesn't like?

This part looks really odd:

```
Caused by: java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: org.apache.reef.wake.remote.impl.DefaultRemoteManagerImplementation.<init>(Ljava/lang/String;Ljava/lang/String;ILorg/apache/reef/wake/remote/Codec;Lorg/apache/reef/wake/EventHandler;ZIILorg/apache/reef/wake/remote/address/LocalAddressProvider;Lorg/apache/reef/wake/remote/ports/TcpPortProvider;)V
        at org.apache.reef.wake.remote.impl.DefaultRemoteManagerFactory.getInstance(DefaultRemoteManagerFactory.java:125)
        at org.apache.reef.runtime.mesos.util.MesosRemoteManager.<init>(MesosRemoteManager.java:44)
        at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method)
        at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:57)
        at sun.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45)
        at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Constructor.java:526)
        at org.apache.reef.tang.implementation.java.InjectorImpl.injectFromPlan(InjectorImpl.java:635)
        ... 28 more
```

This is not a method call by Tang. It is in `DefaultRemoteManagerFactory.getInstance`:

``` java
  public <T> RemoteManager getInstance(String name, Codec<T> codec, EventHandler<Throwable> errorHandler) {
    return new DefaultRemoteManagerImplementation(name,
        DefaultRemoteManagerImplementation.UNKNOWN_HOST_NAME, // Indicate to use the localAddressProvider
        -1, // Indicate to use the tcpPortProvider,
        codec,
        errorHandler,
        this.orderingGuarantee,
        this.numberOfTries,
        this.retryTimeout,
        this.localAddressProvider,
        this.tcpPortProvider);
  }
```

The constructor called does exist in the code base. Hence, my first hunch would be to check whether something went wrong during the compilation process. Are you sure the right bits got compiled and merged into the JAR?

@markusweimer Right, this was my mistake. I had previously done some `hadoop classpath` hacking on the cluster, which brought in classes from an older REEF build. I've cleared the offending classpath entries and have gotten past those message. I'll keep you posted on the results.
